questions.text: Which of the following does not supply the diaphragm?
questions.solution:
The diaphragm is not supplied by the middle phrenic artery

The blood supply of diaphragm is via (Mnemonic - Simple):

  • Superior phrenic arteries
  • Inferior phrenic arteries
  • Musculophrenic arteries
  • Pericardiophrenic arteries
  • Lower 5 intercostal and subcostal arteries

questions.text: The structure passing through the central tendon of the diaphragm is:
questions.solution:
The inferior vena cava passes through the central tendon of the diaphragm.

questions.text: A cardiothoracic surgeon performing a heart transplant accidentally damages the right phrenic nerve. Where does this structure pass through?
questions.solution:
The right phrenic nerve passes through the central tendon of the diaphragm, either by the caval hiatus (labeled 3) or just lateral to it.

Other structures:

  • 1 - Medial arcuate ligament 
  • 2 - Aortic opening 
  • 4 - Esophageal opening

The left phrenic nerve passes through the muscular part of the diaphragm anterior to the central tendon, just lateral to the left cardiac surface and more anterior than the right phrenic nerve.

Clinical significance:

Phrenic nerve injury can occur due to cardiothoracic surgery and can present as diaphragmatic paralysis. On chest X-ray, it appears as elevation of hemidiaphragm.

questions.text: Which of the following structures passes through the area marked A in the given diagram?
questions.solution:
The area marked A represents the medial arcuate ligament. The thoracic sympathetic trunk passes posterior to it and becomes the lumbar sympathetic trunk.

questions.text: A gasteroenterologist is performing an esophagoscopy in a patient with severe acid reflux. At which level will he encounter its diaphragmatic constriction?
questions.solution:
The esophageal hiatus is located at the level of the T10 vertebra, and it forms a normal constriction of the esophagus. It transmits the following:

  • Esophagus
  • Vagal trunks
  • Gastric nerves
  • Esophageal branches of the left gastric vessels and
  • Some lymphatic vessels

Clinical significance:

Anatomical constrictions of the esophagus are important landmarks in esophagoscopy. These are 4 in number and located at a distance from the upper incisors as follows:

  1. 15cm - Cricopharyngeus muscle
  2. 22.5cm - Aortic arch
  3. 27.5cm - Left bronchus
  4. 37.5cm - Diaphragmatic opening

questions.text: A vascular surgeon is operating on a case of aortic dissection of the thoracic aorta. He suspects that the dissection has extended into the abdominal aorta, and approaches the aortic hiatus of the diaphragm to localize the extension. Which of the following structures will be present here?

choices.text: Left gastric vein and thoracic duct
Right vagus nerve and thoracic duct
Left vagus nerve and thoracic duct

questions.solution:
The azygous vein and the thoracic duct are present at the aortic hiatus. These are transmitted along with the thoracic aorta. 

Clinical significance:

Aortic dissection occurs when there's an intimal tear in the aorta. It presents with tearing interscapular pain and extension of dissection into the abdominal aorta can present with abdominal pain. CT/MRI are the investigations of choice. Aortic dissections are classified using the DeBakey and Stanford systems. Depending on the classification, aortic dissections are managed with aggressive antihypertensive therapy or immediate surgical intervention (open/endovascular).

questions.text: Which of the following does not pass through the structure marked A?
questions.solution:
The structure marked A is the aortic opening of the diaphragm.

The vagal trunk does not pass through the aortic opening of the diaphragm. It passes through the esophageal opening at the level of T10 vertebra.

questions.text: A patient with advanced esophageal cancer in the lower third of the esophagus is undergoing transhiatal esophagectomy. The surgeon enlarges the esophageal hiatus with four fingers. All of the following structures are likely to be injured, except:
questions.solution:
The left phrenic nerve is unlikely to be injured as does not pass through any specific opening in the diaphragm. It passes through the muscular part of the diaphragm anterior to the central tendon, just lateral to the left cardiac surface and more anterior than the right phrenic nerve.

Structures passing through the esophageal hiatus are:

  • Esophagus
  • Vagal trunks
  • Gastric nerves
  • Esophageal branches of the left gastric vessels 
  • Some lymphatic vessels

Clinical significance:

In carcinoma esophagus involving the lower third, the Orringer approach or transhiatal esophagectomy is done. The stomach and lower part of esophagus are mobilised via laparotomy and the upper part is mobilized via the left side of the neck. Blunt dissection is done at the hiatus to approach the thorax from the abdomen. Other alternatives to this procedure are robotic and thoracoscopic techniques

questions.text: All of the structures pass posterior to the crus of diaphragm except ____
questions.solution:
The greater splanchnic nerve usually pierces through the crus of the diaphragm to enter the thorax and does not pass posterior to the crus of the diaphragm.

The aortic hiatus is present posterior to the crus of the diaphragm, hence the following structures are likely to be damaged-

  • Aorta
  • Thoracic duct
  • Azygous vein
